properties.description: Defeat of France in the French and Indian War
British policy of salutary neglect towards the colonies for ~150 years
Colonists became accustomed to running their own affairs
British policy towards colonies changed significantly after the French and Indian War
Increased British national debt following the French and Indian War
British Parliament imposed new taxes on colonies to compensate for wartime costs
Control of colonies' western lands turned over to British officials in Montreal
Taxation without representation violated the colonists' rights as Englishmen.
Development of the grievance against taxation without representation, leading to resistance.
Parliament passed the Sugar Act
Parliament passed the Stamp Act, imposing direct taxes for the first time
Colonists objected to their lack of representation in Parliament regarding tax laws.
The grievance was summarized in the slogan 'No taxation without representation'.
Representatives from several colonies convened the Stamp Act Congress
Stamp Act Congress drew up a Declaration of Rights and Grievances
Declaration of Rights and Grievances stated that colonists were equal to other British citizens and taxes without representation violated their rights.
Stamp Act Congress organized a boycott on imports of all British merchandise
Sons of Liberty formed following adoption of the Stamp Act
Sons of Liberty using public demonstration, boycotts, and threats of violence to resist British tax laws.
Sons of Liberty used public demonstrations
Sons of Liberty used boycotts
Sons of Liberty used threats of violence
British tax laws became unenforceable due to Sons of Liberty actions
Parliament repealed the stamp tax
Parliament passed the Declaratory Act stating they retained full power to make laws for colonies 'in all cases whatsoever'
British Parliament passed the Townshend Acts placing duties on goods and establishing a Board of Customs in Boston
Colonists responded to Townshend Acts by organizing new boycotts of British goods
Assembly of Massachusetts Bay Colony issued a circular letter urging colonies to coordinate resistance
Governor dissolved the Massachusetts assembly when it refused to rescind the circular letter
A riot broke out in Boston over the seizure of the sloop Liberty owned by John Hancock
Customs officials were forced to flee Boston
British deployed troops to Boston
Boston town meeting declared no obedience was due to parliamentary laws and called for a convention
Parliament reactivated the Treason Act 1543 calling for trials in England for treason committed outside the realm
The threat of trials under the Treason Act caused widespread outrage in the colonies
British soldiers fired into a crowd, killing protesters
Widespread descriptions of the Boston Massacre began to turn colonial sentiment against the British
Parliament repealed most of the Townshend duties, except the tax on tea
The crisis stemming from the Townshend Acts was temporarily resolved
The boycott of British goods largely ceased
American patriots burned the British warship HMS Gaspee
properties.location: Narragansett Bay, near Warwick, Rhode Island

properties.description: Existence of a systematic plot against American rights by British officials.
Private letters of Governor Hutchinson and Lt. Governor Oliver published, claiming colonists couldn't enjoy all English liberties and calling for direct payment of officials.
Private letters of Massachusetts Governor Hutchinson and Lt. Governor Oliver were published
Letters' contents were used as evidence of a systematic plot against American rights
Governor Hutchinson was discredited in the eyes of the people
Colonial Assembly petitioned for Hutchinson's recall
Benjamin Franklin was removed from his position as postmaster general for leaking the letters
Creation and operation of Committees of Correspondence to link Patriots and coordinate resistance.
Samuel Adams set about creating new Committees of Correspondence in Boston
Committees of Correspondence linked Patriots in all 13 colonies
Virginia set up its Committee of Correspondence
Committees eventually provided the framework for a rebel government
Committees became leaders of the American resistance to British actions
Parliament passed the Tea Act lowering tea price but maintaining the tax, appointing consignees to bypass colonial merchants
Resistance to the Tea Act and British policies was driven by economic self-interest (e.g., smugglers losing business).
The Tea Act was opposed by smugglers who stood to lose business.
Demonstrators warned merchants not to bring in taxed tea
Consignees were forced by Americans to resign or tea was turned back in most colonies
Massachusetts governor Hutchinson refused to allow Boston merchants to give in to pressure
A town meeting in Boston determined the tea would not be landed and ignored the governor's demand to disperse
A group of men, led by Samuel Adams and dressed as Indigenous people, dumped £10,000 worth of tea into Boston Harbor
Process by which British punitive actions in response to colonial resistance escalated the revolutionary cause.
British government responded to the Boston Tea Party by passing four laws known as the Intolerable Acts
Intolerable Act: Massachusetts Government Act altered the Massachusetts charter and restricted town meetings
Intolerable Act: Administration of Justice Act ordered British soldiers to be tried in Britain
Intolerable Act: Boston Port Act closed the port of Boston until compensated for the tea
Intolerable Act: Quartering Act of 1774 allowed royal governors to house British troops in homes without permission
Intolerable Acts further darkened colonial opinion towards England
Massachusetts patriots issued the Suffolk Resolves
An alternative shadow government known as the Provincial Congress was formed
The Provincial Congress began training militia outside British-occupied Boston
The First Continental Congress convened with representatives from 12 colonies
First Continental Congress served as a vehicle for deliberation and collective action
First Continental Congress called for a boycott of all British goods starting December 1, 1774
New local committees authorized by Congress enforced the boycott
First Continental Congress began coordinating Patriot resistance by militias
Militias existed in every colony and had gained military experience in the French and Indian War.
Patriots were armed and unified against Parliament for the first time
American Revolutionary War launched in the Battles of Lexington and Concord
Second Continental Congress convened
Second Continental Congress formed the Continental Army
George Washington appointed commander-in-chief of the Continental Army
Washington and Continental Army responded to battles by surrounding Boston
British forced to withdraw from Boston by sea
Patriots were left in control in every colony
King George III proclaimed Massachusetts to be in a state of open defiance and rebellion
Second Continental Congress began debating and deliberating on the Articles of Confederation
Second Continental Congress passed the Lee Resolution affirming support for national independence
Second Continental Congress unanimously adopted the Declaration of Independence

properties.name: Thomas Jefferson
properties.role: Primary author of Declaration of Independence

properties.description: Declaration of Independence inspired, formalized, and escalated the war
The outcome of the Revolutionary War appeared uncertain for most of its eight-year duration.
For most of the eight-year war, its outcome appeared uncertain.
Decisive victory by Washington and the Continental Army in the Siege of Yorktown, capturing British troops led by Cornwallis
Siege of Yorktown led to the collapse of King George's control of Parliament
Siege of Yorktown led to consensus in Parliament that the war should be ended on American terms
King George III and the British inspired to negotiate an end to colonial rule and acknowledge independence
British signed the Treaty of Paris, codifying independence
Independence of the United States of America from Great Britain achieved
Establishment of the sovereign United States of America
United States became the first constitutional republic in world history founded on consent of the governed and rule of law
The colonists' long-standing practice and desire for self-governance was a primary cause of the rebellion.
Quote from Capt. Levi Preston: "…we always had governed ourselves, and we always meant to. They didn’t mean we should."
Americans had become almost completely self-governing under the British policy of salutary neglect.

properties.source_text_quote: "Americans had become almost completely self-governing" before the American Revolution
"…we always had governed ourselves, and we always meant to. They didn’t mean we should."
its "Declaration of Rights and Grievances" argued that taxation without representation violated their rights as Englishmen
The letters' contents were used as evidence of a systematic plot against American rights
For most of the eight-year war, its outcome appeared uncertain.
